vectorData.altText: 22. What is the action of muscle A?.
That's right!  The abductor pollicis brevis is labelled A. It facilitates abduction of the thumb. Remember, abduction of thumb is different from abduction of the fingers!
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.

This is a good time to review the movements of the thumb     and rectify in your minds the positions of these two muscles with their actions, as described by their names. 
Abduction and flexion occur at the MCP joint, with contraction of the abductor pollicis brevis and the flexor pollicis brevis, respectively. Flexion of the MCP joint pulls the thumb across the palm. Abduction of the MCP joint pulls the thumb out of the plane of the hand.
Remembering that the movements of the thumb occur at right angles the corresponding movements of the fingers.

Look at the position of each muscle and the direction of their muscle fibres. As illustrated by the blue arrow, the abductor pollicis brevis will pull the thumb out of the plane of the palm, and as illustrated by the red arrow, the flexor pollicis brevis will pull the thumb across the palm.
(Flexion also occurs at the IP joint of the thumb with contraction of the     flexor pollicis longus, which you identified in the deep layer of the anterior forearm.)
